questions.text: Aspirin-sensitive asthma is associated with an old male k/c/o ischemic heart disease, recently started on antiplatelet agents, and presented with breathlessness and wheezing. On chest auscultation, he had rhonchi all over. There were no features of heart failure. Which of the following could be found on his general examination?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nasal polyp A subset of patients (5–10%) present in adulthood with difficult-to-control asthma and type 2 inflammation with eosinophilia, sinusitis, nasal polyposis, and severe asthma exacerbations that are precipitated by ingesting inhibitors of cyclooxygenase, with aspirin being the most prominent of such inhibitors. Such patients, classified as having aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease, overproduce leukotrienes in response to the inhibition of cyclooxygenase-1, probably secondary to inhibition of PGE2.

Highyeild:

History of IHD and use of anti-platelet drug - Aspirin Breathlessness and wheezing with rhonchi are the possible asthma features Diagnosis can be Aspirin- sensitive asthma, nasal polyps are seen in aspirin-sensitive asthma

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options: - Option: A. Obesity is not related to aspirin-sensitive asthma Option: B. Urticaria is not seen in aspirin-sensitive asthma, it is mostly seen in allergies of the skin and other commonly related problems Option: D. Aspirin-sensitive asthma is not of the extrinsic type

questions.text: All of the following are true about Kartagener's syndrome, Except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mental retardation Kartagener ‘s syndrome includes dextrocardia, infertility, and bronchiectasis as its main clinical features. The symptoms occur due to the immotile cilia formation and mental retardation is not a feature seen Kartagener's syndrome is a rare, autosomal recessive genetic ciliary disorder comprising the triad of situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis . The basic problem lies in the defective movement of cilia, leading to recurrent chest infections, ear/nose/throat symptoms, and infertility.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has been experiencing recurrent attacks of asthma, for which he is on treatment. Recently, he has also started experiencing nasal blockage and nasal discharge, for which he visited an ENT specialist. He was found to have Bilateral Nasal polyposis. As his Doctor, which of the following drugs will you tell the patient he is sensitive to and hence, should not be prescribed to him?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aspirin This is a case of Samter’s triad or AERD (Aspirin exacerbated respiratory disease), characterised by Bronchial asthma, Nasal polyposis and Aspirin sensitivity . Such patients overproduce leukotrienes in response to the inhibition of COX-1, probably secondary to the inhibition of PGE2. Treatment Option:s include ICS, leukotriene modifiers, Aspirin desensitisation and biologicals against IL 4 and IL 5.

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option:s A, C, and D are not associated with asthma exacerbations.

questions.text: A patient presented to the emergency room with acute onset of shortness of breath, which is present at rest. He is severely dyspneic and is unable to complete sentences. On examination, his pulse rate is 120 bpm, respiratory rate is 35/min, and Spo2 under room air is 93%. He is afebrile, there is no cyanosis or clubbing. On chest examination, he has Bilateral polyphonic loud wheeze. Which of the following will not be used as a treatment Option: for him?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Theophylline The clinical scenario presented is of an Acute exacerbation of bronchial asthma, which can be a life-threatening emergency if not treated timely. Theophylline or Aminophylline are not recommended for the treatment of acute asthma exacerbations according to the latest guidelines. They have a very narrow therapeutic range and hence, require close monitoring. Oxygen inhalation, Subcutaneous bronchodilators and corticosteroids play a vital role in the management of asthma exacerbations.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in the management of bronchial asthma?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ustekinumab Ustekinumab is a monoclonal antibody targeting both IL-12 and IL-23 used for the treatment of Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis, plaque psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options: - Option: A. Mepolizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody targeting IL-5 . It can be used for the treatment of severe eosinophilic asthma, eosinophilic granulomatosis, and hypereosinophilic syndrome. Option: B. Dupilumab targets IL-4 and IL-13, it is approved for use in Atopic dermatitis, Asthma, Chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyposis and Eosinophilic esophagitis. Option: D. Lebrikizumab is an IL-13 blocker which is used for the treatment of asthma that cannot be adequately controlled with ICS.

Extraedge:

Dupilumab reduces exacerbations by ≥50%, decreases symptoms, and may produce more of an effect on FEV1 than anti–IL-5 drugs. It gradually reduces FeNO and IgE levels. Paradoxically, circulating eosinophil counts may initially temporarily increase. Most effects are seen by 3–6 months of therapy.

questions.text: A patient with bronchial asthma was subjected to a sputum examination. Which of the following findings in the sputum does not support the diagnosis of asthma?
questions.explanation:

Shows Charcot–Leyden crystals which are microscopic crystals composed of eosinophil protein galectin-10 found in people who have allergic diseases such as asthma or parasitic infections such as parasitic pneumonia or ascariasis.

questions.text: Bronchial asthma is characterised by episodic reversible airway obstruction and airway hyper-responsiveness usually accompanied by airway inflammation. Which of the following supports the same?

options.label: C
options.text: Increase in FEV1 by 350 ml post bronchodilator

options.label: D
options.text: Drop in FEV1 by 15% on the Methacholine challenge test

questions.correct_answer: C. Increase in FEV1 by 350 ml post bronchodilator
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increase in FEV1 by 350 ml post bronchodilator Increase in FEV1 by 350 ml post Bronchodilator\\Reversibility is defined as a ≥12% increase in the FEV1 and an absolute increase of ≥200 mL at least 15 min after administration of a β2-agonist or after several weeks of corticosteroid therapy. Diurnal peak flow variability of >20% has also been proposed as an indicator of reversible airway disease, but it is less reliable due to difficulties with quality control and variability of home assessments. Lung volumes and diffusing capacity should be normal in uncomplicated asthma.

A provocative dose producing a 20% drop in FEV1 (PD20) is calculated, with a value ≤400 μg indicative of airway reactivity.
